recommendations: Admission to hospital for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia with COPD exacerbation
Empiric antibiotics: beta-lactam (ceftriaxone or ampicillin-sulbactam) plus macrolide (azithromycin) OR respiratory fluoroquinolone monotherapy (levofloxacin) given penicillin allergy
Consider short course systemic corticosteroids given COPD exacerbation component
Blood cultures and sputum culture prior to antibiotic administration
Monitor blood glucose given history of diabetes and infection-related hyperglycemia risk
Consider thromboprophylaxis given hospitalization for acute medical illness
conclusion: This 68-year-old male with COPD presents with clinical and radiographic evidence of community-acquired pneumonia affecting the right lower lobe, along with features of COPD exacerbation. The moderate severity (CURB-65 score of 2) warrants inpatient management with appropriate antibiotics, supplemental oxygen, bronchodilators, and supportive care. His comorbidities (COPD, diabetes, hypertension) increase his risk for complications and should be addressed in the management plan.
